results.title: Conservation in the Snowy Mountains
results.brief_description: Emphasises the importance of soil conservation in the catchment areas of the Snowy Mountains and illustrates how erosion is being controlled. Erosion in the Snowy area is due to the removal of vegetation through excessive grazing, burning off and the construction of roads. Ways in which this is being handled are prevention of fires, re-vegetation, control of grazing, building of brush fences and matting, and contour ploughing.

results.title: Concerto for orchestra
results.creator_credit: Robert Parker, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The life and work of members of the Sydney Symphony Orchestra and its resident conductor, Dean Dixon, the off-duty hobbies and pastimes of members of the orchestra, ranging from surf fishing and motor racing to violin making and chess. Highlight is an invitation by the conductor to kindergarten children to play the instrument of their choice. Features music of Bela Bartok.

results.title: Constructing Australia
results.creator_credit: Alex West, Film Australia, Piper Films, Prospero Productions and Real Pictures
results.brief_description: The Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Kalgoorlie Pipeline and the Overland Telegraph were amongst Australia’s most significant civil engineering projects. “Constructing Australia” is a series of three films - “The Bridge”, “Pipe Dreams” and “A Wire Through the Heart” - that tells the story behind these landmarks in the construction of white Australian society. Combining dramatic re-enactments with archival footage, documentary sources, and interviews, the three films deal not only with the practical challenges and problems that faced each of the projects, but also reveal the personal triumphs and tragedies, the political intrigues, the human dramas and the social contexts behind these pioneering events.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex West, Film Australia, Piper Films, Prospero Productions and Real Pictures

results.title: Conservation conscious
results.creator_credit: Anna Jeffries, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and QPIX Ltd
results.brief_description:
Richard McDonald and Vicki Locke are two very dedicated and passionate art conservators who work from their solar-powered home in the Sunshine Coast Hinterland’s rainforest. Being “conservation conscious” is not only reflected in their work but also in their philosophy on life.
A mini-documentary written, directed and edited by Anna Jeffries with cinematography and music by Nick Batterham.

results.title: Consenting adult
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Cates, David Lawrence, Ray Aghayan and Starger Company
results.brief_description: Set in the pre-AIDS era, this made for television film focuses on the story of a family torn apart when their son announces he is a “homosexual”. All American college student Jeff Lynd (Barry Tubb) is the only son of an ill and emotionally inept father (Martin Sheen) and well intentioned home-maker mother (Marlo Thomas). Fearing his father’s reaction, Jeff comes out to his mother and asks her for help, she misinterprets this as believing he wants to be “cured” and sends her son to a psychiatrist. When her husband finds out Jeff is gay and does not want to be “cured”, he disowns him, fracturing the family further. Jeff finds a sympathetic ear with his married sister Margie (Talia Balsam), but remains estranged from his father until death finally brings them tenuously and posthumously together. Jeff comes out in the first fifteen minutes of the film, consequently the remainder of the film is about how the family react to the news; shock, disbelief, anger and confused acceptance. The representation of Jeff’s sexual awakening is chastely portrayed off screen; presumably it’s the content matter that has prescribed the M rating. Based on the novel by Laura Z. Hobson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gilbert Cates, David Lawrence, Ray Aghayan and Starger Company

results.title: Conquering the continent
results.creator_credit: Kelvin Hogarth and Outback Explorers Video Productions
results.brief_description: As Burke and Wills lay dying at Cooper Creek, a determined Scotsman was already planning his third transcontinental expedition. John McDouall Stuart had explored much of South Australia and penetrated to the very centre of Australia. His perseverance paid off when, on 24th July 1862, he finally reached the Indian Ocean. Stuart had succeeded in discovering a reliable route right across the continent. Upon reading of Stuart’s explorations, a father and his three young children were inspired to head off and attempt to retrace Stuart’s last and greatest expedition. With the children helping to operate the camera, they brought back a pictorial record of Stuart’s country as it is today. The story begins as an historical narrative but soon becomes a great Outback adventure. They enter isolated country seldom visited these days. It took them six weeks to do what had taken Stuart fourteen months to do as they covered the 12,000km return journey along Stuart’s route.

results.title: Conquerant de L'inutile = Borders of the Impossible
results.brief_description:
This documentary tells the life story of Lionel Terray who became one of the most famous French mountaineer after World War II. The footage used in this documentary has been filmed by friends and fellow mountaineers like Maurice Herzog and Jacques Ertaud. It contains breathtaking scenes of expeditions conducted by Terray in the Himalayas and the Andes.

Credits: Director, Marcel Ichac ; music, Francois de Roubaix.

results.title: Comradeship
results.creator_credit: G Pabst, Aubert Film, Franco-Film, Gaumont and Nero-Film
results.brief_description: The dramatic story of a mining disaster shortly after World War I on the French-German border. Post war tension and bitterness are put aside when the German miners help rescue their French comrades. Emphasising worker solidarity. In German and French with English subtitles.

results.title: Congo: the way ahead
results.creator_credit: Frank Jacoby, Robert Morgan, George Movshon and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description: Through the eyes of a 15-year-old Congo schoolboy, reveals the current (1963) situation in the Congo. The tragic circumstances which since 1960 have led to a decline in the standards of living of millions of people - the story of the patient painstaking efforts of the Congo people to build a modern and flourishing state are vividly portrayed, and the UN efforts to help.
